snippet: The swift military expansion and island-building efforts have raised tensions while advancing China’s goal of a security buffer far from its coast.
abstract: Rapid Chinese buildup of outposts and artificial islands in South China Sea has many United States officials and analysts worried that China will soon have de facto control over large expanse, potentially impeding US efforts to come to aid or defense of its allies in region.

byline.original: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE and JANE PERLEZ
byline.contributor: Michael Forsythe reported from Hong Kong, and Jane Perlez from Beijing. Yufan Huang contributed research from Beijing.

lead_paragraph: The swift military expansion and island-building efforts have raised tensions while advancing China’s goal of a security buffer far from its coast.

headline.main: South China Sea Buildup Brings Beijing Closer to Realizing Control
headline.print_headline: South China Sea Buildup Strengthens Beijing’s Claims

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
